docs.lead_paragraph: Caremark Rx said today the government wanted documents about its relationship with TAP Pharmaceutical Products, which paid a record fine last year to settle a health care fraud case. Caremark said it received two subpoenas on Thursday from the United States attorney's office in Boston that focus on TAP's cancer drug Lupron and its ulcer drug Prevacid. The company, which manages pharmacy benefits for customers, said it was not the target of the investigation and was cooperating with the government.

headline.main: U.S. Asks Caremark Rx for Documents

docs.abstract: Hope Alexander-Griscom letter on May 10 article urges Americans to take responsibility for own health instead of paying health care industry to manage consequences of poor diets and lifestyle habits
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Companies Trim Health Benefits for Many Retirees as Costs Surge'' (front page, May 10):

docs.lead_paragraph: After 25 years of providing insurance against suits for medical malpractice, the company that insured nearly 40 percent of New Jersey's doctors is shutting its doors, leaving the doctors scrambling for coverage just as other insurers are getting out of the business or cutting back. The demise of the insurer, the MIIX Group, which was founded by New Jersey doctors when no one else would sell them coverage at anything like affordable prices, deepens a health care crisis that has been growing in New Jersey and around the country.

headline.main: New Jersey Insurer Is Leaving Many Doctors Scrambling

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate leaders and the White House reached agreement today on a broad trade package that includes subsidized health insurance for American workers who are displaced by foreign competition, clearing the way for Senate approval as early as next week of new trade negotiating authority sought by President Bush. The deal, reached after weeks of talks and partisan jousting, brought the White House close to achieving a top legislative priority: the right of the president to make trade deals that Congress could not change but only ratify or reject.

headline.main: White House and Senate in Trade Accord

docs.abstract: Senate leaders and White House reach agreement on broad trade package that includes subsidized health insurance for American workers who are displaced by foreign competition, clearing way for Senate approval of new trade negotiating authority sought by Pres Bush; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of retired workers who used to have generous health benefits from large companies are digging deeper into their own pockets this year. Surging inflation in medical costs is draining hundreds of millions of dollars from corporate profits, and many large employers are responding by cutting back on health care benefits for retirees or requiring them to pay more for coverage. The reductions in health benefits stem mainly from sudden sharp increases in employer spending on prescription drugs last year. Drugs account for 40 to 60 percent of employers' overall spending on Medicare-age retirees' health care. At the same time, far-reaching cutbacks by Medicare health maintenance organizations -- which used to provide generous benefits, including drug coverage -- are forcing employers to pay for retirees' drug coverage, since traditional Medicare does not cover the cost of most drugs.

headline.main: Companies Trim Health Benefits For Many Retirees as Costs Surge

docs.abstract: Surging inflation in medical costs prompts many large employers to cut back on health care benefits for retirees, or to require them to pay more for coverage; reductions in health benefits stem mainly from sudden sharp increases in employer spending on prescription drugs last year; drugs account for 40 to 60 percent of employers' overall spending on Medicare-age retirees' health care; Medicare health maintenance organizations, which used to provide generous benefits, including drug coverage, have made far-reaching cutbacks, forcing employers to pay for retirees' drug coverage, since traditional Medicare does not cover cost of most drugs; as result, current health care costs for retirees are soaring 18 percent a year, on average, and large companies' liabilities for future health care costs for retirees are rising as much as 34 percent; many medium-size companies have stopped promising retiree health care coverage to new hires; photos; chart (L)
docs.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of retired workers who used to have generous health benefits from large companies are digging deeper into their own pockets this year. Surging inflation in medical costs is draining hundreds of millions of dollars from corporate...

docs.lead_paragraph: Worker claims for jobless benefits fell less than expected last week, and the number of Americans collecting aid rose to a 19-year high, government figures showed today, suggesting that the labor market is not improving rapidly as the economy recovers. States received 411,000 new applications for unemployment benefits in the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. Though that figure was down 11,000 from the previous week, it was more than the 407,000 that economists had expected. About 3.8 million workers collected unemployment benefits in the week ended April 27, the most since April 1983 during a recovery from back-to-back recessions.

headline.main: New Data on Unemployment Question Health of Labor Market

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports states received 411,000 new applicants for unemployment benefits in week ended May 4, down 11,000 from previous week; about 3.8 million workers collected unemployment benefits in week ended April 27; Goldman, Sachs retail composite index shows sales at retail stores open at least year rose 0.8 percent in April; government report shows import prices were 3.9 percent lower in April than year ago; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Israel Moves Toward Gaza; Siege Lifts in Bethlehem Israel sent tanks toward the Gaza Strip, called up reservists and threatened airstrikes as it prepared to retaliate for the Palestinian suicide attack near Tel Aviv that killed 15 Israelis. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was not swayed by Yasir Arafat's announcement that his forces would stop future attacks. In Bethlehem, after several false starts and last-minute delays, Palestinians began to file out of the besieged Church of the Nativity one by one. A1 The Hamas bombing was aimed not only at Israelis but also sought to undermine the credibility of Mr. Arafat and his Palestinian Authority, Palestinian officials and analysts say. A16 American support for Israel is driving a grass-roots boycott of American consumer goods in the Arab world. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Andersen Prosecutors Accused of Intimidation A lawyer for Arthur Andersen accused federal prosecutors of trying to intimidate at least three witnesses by threatening them with indictment and said he would submit an immediate request to the Justice Department for an investigation. The accusation came after a day of hearings during which prosecutors disclosed that an Andersen partner had told an Enron lawyer in December that he had deleted e-mail messages, an indication that Andersen knew about the destruction of records weeks earlier than previously believed. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush, who managed to ram an important free-trade bill through the House by a one-vote margin, now has a chance to get it through the Senate and into law. To do it he will have to throw his weight behind a useful Democratic proposal aimed at softening the impact of trade agreements on workers who lose their jobs. The bill would give Mr. Bush ''fast track'' powers to negotiate a broad new international trade agreement that Congress would have to approve or reject without amendment. It has had a Perils of Pauline history, and to get it through the House Mr. Bush made several side deals favoring certain industries important to the lucky representatives who happened to be swing votes.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Pres Bush to support proposal by Senate Democrats to provide health care benefits to American workers who lose their jobs to foreign competition; plan would be added to bill granting Bush 'fast track' powers to negotiate broad new international trade agreement (M)
